question.name: 37.1.1.3 General permutations
question.questiontext:
In general we can order \(n\) distinct objects in \(n!\) ways.
Suppose we have \(r\) different types of object. It follows that if we have \(n_1\) objects of one kind, \(n_2\) of another kind and so on then the \(n_1\) objects can be ordered in \(n_1!\) ways, the \(n_2\) objects in \(n_2!\) ways and so on. If \(n_1+n_2+\dots +n_r=n\) and if \(p\) is the number of permutations possible from \(n\) objects we may write
\[\qquad p\times (n_1!\times n_2!\times\dots \times n_r!)=n!\]
and so \(p\) is given by the formula
\[\displaystyle{\qquad p=\frac{n!}{n_1!\times n_2!\times\dots \times n_r!}}.\]
Very often we will find it useful to be able to calculate the number of permutations of \(n\) objects taken \(r\) at a time. Assuming that we do not allow repetitions, we may choose the first object in \(n\) ways, the second in \(n-1\) ways, the third in \(n-2\) ways and so on so that the \(r^{\text{th}}\) object may be chosen in \(n-r+1\) ways.
